Graphical abstract A series of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts are prepared by the methods of wet impregnation (IM), deposition-precipitation (DP), solid state ion exchange (SSIE), and modified solid state ion exchange (MSSIE), and used for catalytic decomposition of ammonia to COx-free hydrogen. Their physicochemical properties are characterized by XRD, N2 sorption, TEM, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, solid-state NMR, and XPS techniques. It is revealed that the preparation methods could obviously influence the Ni species and catalytic performance of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts, and the catalyst prepared by MSSIE method exhibits the best catalytic activity due to the presence of strong metal-support interaction between highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles and ZSM-5 support. The stability testing results showed almost no activity loss over Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalyst at 650 °C for 60 h, indicating a very promising catalyst for ammonia decomposition. Keywords Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts Ammonia decomposition Hydrogen production Nanocatalysts Metal-support interaction 1 Introduction As a clean and efficient energy resource, hydrogen has received great attentions over the past several decades. However, the handling difficulty and low energy density by volume of hydrogen seriously impede its wide application. So, many researches are focused on the exploitation of efficient hydrogen carriers, such as ammonia, methanol, formic acid and ammonia borane [1–3]. Among them, ammonia is regarded as one of the most promising candidates for H2 production due to its mass production, high H2 content (17.6 wt%), easy liquefaction and transportation [4–6]. Most importantly, on-site generation of H2 from ammonia can efficiently avoid the COx which is harmful to proton-exchange membrane fuel cells [7,8]. Thus, the catalytic decomposition of ammonia is seemed as a very promising way for H2 production, and much effort has been devoted to exploit efficient catalysts including noble metal (Ru, Ir, Pd, etc.) and non-noble metal (Fe, Co, Ni, etc.) catalysts for ammonia decomposition [9–14]. Particularly, Ni-based catalysts are regarded as one kind of very promising catalysts for ammonia decomposition due to their high catalytic activity, low price and long-term stability [15–20]. It has been known that loading Ni particles on the appropriate supports such as metal oxides, zeolites, mesoporous silica and nanocarbons would give rise to increase the catalytic performance of Ni-based catalysts [21–24], due to the change of their several properties (such as Ni particle sizes and distribution, reducibility, and metal-support interactions). Indeed, the catalytic activity and especially the stability of metal catalysts strongly depend on both the state and structure of the support and the specific interaction between metal and support [25,26]. The type of the support is of crucial importance to the obtaining of highly dispersed Ni particles and catalysts with good performance. It is also demonstrated that the supported Ni nanoparticles with small size and high dispersion are more active than bulk ones in ammonia decomposition [27–29]. And the core-shell structure of Ni@SiO2 catalysts could efficiently prevent from the sintering of nano-sized Ni species at high reaction temperature and the subsequent deactivation, exhibiting improved thermal stability of Ni nanoparticles for ammonia decomposition [30,31]. However, the shell thickness of SiO2 layer is hard to control, and the increasing shell thickness of SiO2 layer had a negative influence on the catalytic activity of Ni@SiO2 catalysts [32,33]. Thus, it is quite significant to exploit a Ni-based catalyst with both high catalytic activity and long term stability. Recent reports have shown that the metal nanoparticles onto porous supports (such as zeolites, porous carbon and hydrotalcite) with strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) could simultaneously increase the activity and thermal stability of the supported catalysts in high-temperature reactions [34–37]. Among these porous supports, zeolite ZSM-5 possesses good thermal stability, large surface area and tunable acidity, which represents a promising support to disperse and confine nanoparticles [38,39]. Qi et al. reported that nano-sized Ni catalyst supported on ZSM-5 exhibited high catalytic stability and activity due to the presence of appropriate metal-support interaction between Ni and ZSM-5 support [40]. Furthermore, a series of Ni-ZSM-5 zeolites were synthesized by ion exchange method for various reactions such as methane to methanol [41], NO reduction [42], and isobutane and n-butane cracking [43], and the Ni ions could be stabilized into the ZSM-5 structure by chemical interaction, though only a small amount of Ni species can be exchanged into the structure of ZSM-5. Meanwhile, a modified dry impregnation method using dealuminated zeolites and metal salts (such as titanocene dichloride, titanocene dichloride and zirconocene dichloride) was reported for synthesis of metal-zeolite catalysts, in which the zeolite was dealuminated to generate silanols prior to grafting metal species [44–47]. Very recently, Dai et al. proposed a similar method to prepare Zn-Y-beta by mixing dealuminated H-beta with nitrates, and the catalytic activity and stability of the zeolite catalysts could be significantly enhanced due to the confinement effect of zeolite cages [48]. Herein, we proposed a modified solid state ion exchange method for preparation of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts by grinding of dealuminated ZSM-5 with nickel nitrate. And the prepared Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts were used for ammonia decomposition, exhibiting high catalytic activity and excellent thermal stability. Furthermore, to make clear the influence of preparation methods on the catalytic performance of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts in ammonia decomposition, other three Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation, deposition-precipitation, and solid state ion exchange method. The structural and textural property, acidity, reducibility and Ni particle size of the prepared Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts were measured by XRD, N2 sorption, TEM, NH3-TPD, solid-state NMR, H2-TPR, and XPS techniques. The effect of the preparation methods on the catalytic performance of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts were investigated in detail. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts H-ZSM-5 zeolite with Si/Al ratio of 43 was obtained from Tianjin Shenneng Sci-Tech Co., Ltd. The Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts were prepared by four different methods namely wet impregnation (IM), deposition-precipitation (DP), solid state ion exchange (SSIE) and modified solid state ion exchange (MSSIE) methods. Ni(NO3)·6H2O and NH3·6H2O were obtained from the Tianjin Guangfu Fine Chemical. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. For IM preparation, the calculated Ni(NO3)·6H2O was dissolved into deionized water and stirred for 1 h. Then, 2 g of dried H-ZSM-5 was added into the above solution and stirred at 80 °C until the solution was evaporated. Afterwards, the sample was dried at 110 °C for 12 h and subsequently calcined at 600 °C for 6 h. The resultant sample was denoted as Ni/ZSM-5(IM). For DP preparation, the calculated Ni(NO3)·6H2O was dissolved into deionized water and stirred for 1 h. Then, 2 g of dried H-ZSM-5 was added into the solution and stirred for 1 h. 0.2 M NH3·6H2O was dropped into the above mixture until pH = 9 of the solution, and aged for 2 h. Subsequently, the mixture was filtered, washed, and dried at 110 °C for 12 h. The resultant solid sample was calcined at 600 °C for 6 h, and named as Ni/ZSM-5(DP). For SSIE preparation, the calculated Ni(NO3)·6H2O was mechanically ground with H-ZSM-5 for 1 h. Then the mixture was transformed into muffle furnace and maintained at 300 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, the above sample was calcined at 600 °C for 6 h, and denoted as Ni/ZSM-5(SSIE). For MSSIE preparation, the HZSM-5 was firstly dealuminated by 13 M HNO3 solution for 12 h at 80 °C, followed by drying at 200 °C for 24 h, which was named deAlZSM-5. Afterwards, the calculated Ni(NO3)·6H2O was mechanically ground with the deAlZSM-5 zeolite for 1 h. And the mixture was transformed into muffle furnace and maintained at 300 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, the above sample was calcined at 600 °C for 6 h, and named as Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE). 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Focus diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, 40 kV, 40 mA). N2 sorption experiments were conducted on a Quantachrome Autosorb-1MP sorption analyzer. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out on a Jeol JEM-2800 microscope at 200 kV. Ammonia temperature programed desorption (NH3-TPD) analysis was performed on a Quantachrome ChemBET 3000 analyzer. Before each test, 0.2 g sample was degassed in helium gas at 600 °C for 30 min. Then, the degassed sample was cooled down to 80 °C and subsequently exposed in NH3 flow (5 vol%, 20 ml min−1) for 30 min. Afterwards, the residue was purged by a flow of He (20 ml min−1) until the baseline flat. Finally, desorption was conducted in He (20 ml min−1) with the heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Hydrogen temperature programed reduction (H2-TPR) analysis was tested on a Quantachrome ChemBET 3000 analyzer. And the sample was degassed in He flow (20 ml min−1) at 400 °C for 1 h before the test. Afterwards, the degassed sample was reduced by the 10% H2/Ar flow (20 ml min−1). Solid-state NMR spectroscopy was carried out on a Bruker AVC400 spectrometer at resonance frequencies of 79.5 and 104.3 MHz for 29Si and 27Al, respectively. The 29Si MAS NMR spectra were tested after π/4 single pulse excitations, with repetition of 10 s at a spinning rate of 5 kHz. The 27Al MAS NMR spectra were tested after π/6 single pulse excitations, with repetition times of 0.5 s at a spinning rate of 8 kHz. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiment was carried out on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer. All the spectra were corrected by the containment carbon (C 1 s) at 284.8 eV. 2.3 Catalytic testing The ammonia decomposition experiments over Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts for ammonia decomposition were tested in a fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. Typically, 0.1 g of the catalyst (sieve fraction 300 ∼ 500 μm) was put into a quartz reactor (5 mm i.d.) and in-situ reduced by flowing H2 (20 ml min−1) at 600 °C for 1 h. After cooling down to room temperature, pure ammonia (50 ml min−1) was introduced into the reactor and purged for 1 h. And the corresponding gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) is 30,000 ml h−1 g−1. Then, the reactor was heated to the desired temperature, and the products were analyzed by an on-line gas chromatograph (GC, SP-6800A6). The catalytic activity was calculated as the ammonia conversion, and the H2 formation rate was calculated from the H2 content in the out gas. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties of the prepared catalysts The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of raw ZSM-5, dealuminated ZSM-5 and 5%Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) are shown in Fig. S1, and the corresponding structural properties are listed in Table 1 . As shown in Fig. S1, the N2 sorption isotherms of raw ZSM-5 are of type I according to the IUPAC, typical for microporous material. After dealuminaiton, no obvious changes of the sorption isotherms can be observed over the deAlZSM-5, indicating the preserve of ZSM-5 framework structure. While the S BET of deAlZSM-5 (423 m2 g−1) shows a slight increase as compared to the raw ZSM-5 (385 m2 g−1), which is probably due to the formation of many vacant T sites with associated silanol groups during the dealumination process [44,45]. After loading 5% Ni species, the N2 sorption isotherms of the 5%Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) are almost coincided with those of the raw ZSM-5, probably because the Ni species are incorporated into the ZSM-5 framework at the Al sites [44]. However, the BET surface areas of 5%Ni/ZSM-5 prepared by SSIE, DP and IM methods show a slight decrease as compared to the raw ZSM-5, due to the low dispersed Ni species blocking a number of pores. 3.2 Catalytic activity and stability of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts Catalytic activities of 5%Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts (prepared by IM, DP, SSIE and MSSIE) in ammonia decomposition are shown in Fig. 1 , and the corresponding H2 formation rates are shown in Fig. S2. Clearly, the catalytic performances of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts are various with the preparation methods. As shown in Fig. 1, the ammonia decomposition for all the Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts occurs at temperature about 300 ∼ 400 °C. And the ammonia conversion increases with the reaction temperature, in accordance with the endothermic character of the ammonia decomposition reaction. Among these catalysts, the Ni/ZSM-5 prepared by MSSIE method shows the highest catalytic activity. At 650 °C, 97.6% ammonia conversion with about 32.7 mmol min−1 gcat −1 H2 formation rate can be obtained for 5%Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE), which is comparable to that of previous reported Fe/Co-containing CNTs [49] and much higher than Fe/CNFs [8], Ni/CNFs [21], and Ni/red mud [27,28]. And the detailed comparable information is shown in Table S1. While, 50.1%, 81.3% and 92.9% ammonia conversion is obtained over the catalysts prepared by IM, DP and SSIE at 650 °C, respectively, suggesting their lower catalytic activity than MSSIE-prepared Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst. The catalytic activity of the dealuminated ZSM-5 and Ni/ZSM-5 prepared by MSSIE methods with different Ni loading amounts are shown in Fig. 2 , and the corresponding H2 formation rates are shown in Fig. S3. As shown in Fig. 2, the dealuminated ZSM-5 shows almost no catalytic activity for ammonia decomposition even at the reaction temperature up to 650 °C. After loading Ni species, the Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) samples exhibit much higher activity than deAlZSM-5, suggesting the main active sites of Ni species. Meanwhile, the catalytic activities of Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalysts increase with the Ni content from 0 to 5%. And the Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst with 5% Ni content exhibits the highest catalytic activity. However, when the Ni content exceeds this value, the catalytic activity would gradually decrease with the further increase of Ni loading amount in the catalysts. In ammonia decomposition reaction, the prepared catalysts have a problem of deactivation because they easily sinter into large particles when they are performed at high reaction temperature over 400 °C [37,46]. And the preparation of efficient catalyst with high thermal stability for ammonia decomposition is crucial for its commercial application. Fig. 3 shows the catalytic stability of the most active catalyst of 5%Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE), and the catalytic reaction was conducted at a fixed condition (0.1 g, 30,000 ml h−1 g−1, 50 ml min−1, 650 °C). Clearly, the 5%Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalyst exhibits excellent stability. The ammonia conversion and H2 formation rate of the 5%Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalyst keep at around 97% and 33 mmol min−1 gcat −1, respectively, without obvious deactivation for 60 h time-on-stream. Such an excellent catalytic stability of Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) could be attributed to the highly stable Ni nanoparticles attached onto the ZSM-5 support [32,50]. 3.3 Characterization of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts In order to investigate the nature of Ni species in Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts, the prepared catalysts were characterized by several techniques including XRD, TEM, NH3-TPD, solid-state NMR, H2-TPR and XPS. The XRD patterns of 5%Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by different methods are shown in Fig. 4 a. Clearly, all the XRD patterns possess typical diffraction peaks characteristic of MFI structure, suggesting that the Ni loading makes little influence on the ZSM-5 framework structure. While no obvious diffraction peaks of Ni species can be observed in the 5%Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts, probably because the Ni species are highly dispersed onto the ZSM-5 zeolites or the Ni contents are too low to be detected [29,30]. The XRD patterns of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by MSSIE methods with different Ni contents are shown in Fig. 4b. It is seen that only when the Ni content increases to 7% and more, three new diffraction peaks at 2θ = 37.2°, 43.3° and 62.9° corresponding to the (111), (200) and (220) crystallite planes of NiO (JCPDS No. 47-1049), respectively, can be observed, and these diffraction peaks become stronger and narrower with the increase of the Ni loading amount, indicating the growth of NiO nanoparticles [27,32]. The XRD patterns of the used catalysts are shown in Fig. S4. Clearly, two small and broad peaks at 2θ = 44.5° and 51.8° can be observed in all the samples, characteristic of cubic Ni phase (JCPDS No. 65-2865). Fig. S4a shows the used Ni/ZSM-5 prepared by different methods, however, no obvious changes can be observed over these 5%Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst. Fig. S4b shows the used Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalysts with different Ni content. It can be seen that the intensities of Ni peaks progressively increase with the Ni content, indicating the increase of crystallinity and the growth of Ni nanoparticles with the increase of Ni loading amount. The microstructure and micromorphology of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts were characterized by TEM (Fig. 5 ). Fig. 5a and b show the TEM images of 5%Ni/ZSM-5 prepared by MSSIE method, and the corresponding particle size distribution is shown in Fig. 5c. Clearly, the NiO nanoparticles are well dispersed onto the ZSM-5 surface with uniform particle size in the range of 3–13 nm. The high resolution TEM images show clear lattice fringes with interplanar spacing of 0.24 nm, corresponding to the (111) plane of NiO [51,52]. While the Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by DP and IM methods (Fig. 5d-i) possess larger particle size and lower dispersions as compared to the MSSIE-prepared sample. And the sizes of NiO nanoparticles in the DP- and IM-prepared samples are in the range of 5–32 and 10–28 nm, respectively. The high resolution TEM images of DP- and IM-prepared samples (Fig. 5e and h) show lattice fringes with interplanar spacing of 0.24 nm, corresponding to the (111) crystal plane of NiO, which is the same to MSSIE sample. This result confirms that the preparation method has a significant impact on the Ni particle size and dispersion. Fig. S5 shows the TEM images of the used 5%Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by MSSIE, DP and IM methods. It is shown that the 5%Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE)-used catalyst exhibits the highest dispersion and smallest particle size than DP and IM samples. The acidic properties of raw ZSM-5, dealuminated ZSM-5 and Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by different methods were investigated by NH3-TPD (Fig. 6 ), and the corresponding data are shown in Table 1. As shown in Fig. 6a, three obvious NH3 desorption peaks can be observed in raw ZSM-5, corresponding to the desorption of physisorbed NH3 (weak acid sites, 50–300 °C), weakly adsorbed NH3 (moderate strong acid sites, 150 ∼ 400 °C) and strongly adsorbed NH3 (strong acid sites, 400–600 °C), respectively [53,54]. After dealumination by concentrated HNO3, the acid amount decreases obviously due to the removal of partial Al species (Si−OH-Al). Inagaki et al. have well reported that post-synthetic HNO3-treatment of ZSM-5 could remove framework Al selectively from the external surface, producing a vacant sites-rich ZSM-5 [55]. Upon Ni precursor mixing with dealuminated ZSM-5, the acid sites recover to some extent. And the total acid amount of Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) (0.392 mmol g−1) is a little higher than that of raw ZSM-5 (0.275 mmol g−1), indicating that many Ni species are successfully incorporated into the ZSM-5 framework at the Al sites (forming Si−OH-Ni species) [48,56]. Fig. 6b shows the NH3-TPD curves of 5%Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by SSIE, IM, and DP methods. All these three samples possess similar NH3-TPD curves, indicating similar acidity types and contents. It is notable that the strong acid amounts (centered at ∼550 °C) of 5%Ni/ZSM-5(SSIE) (0.039 mmol g−1), 5%Ni/ZSM-5(IM) (0.033 mmol g−1) and 5%Ni/ZSM-5(DP) (0.023 mmol g−1) are much lower than that of 5%Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) (0.102 mmol g−1). Fig. S6 depicts the solid-state NMR spectra of raw ZSM-5 and dealuminated ZSM-5. The 27Al MAS NMR spectrum of the raw ZSM-5 (Si/Al = 43) shows two peaks at 1 and 55 ppm, corresponding to the six-coordinated extra-framework and four-coordinated framework Al, respectively [57,58]. After dealumination by concentrated HNO3, the intensity of these two signals decreases to some extent, suggesting that a part of Al species are wiped off during the dealumination process. This result is in good accordance with the NH3-TPD analysis in Fig. 6. The corresponding 29Si MAS NMR spectra are shown in Fig. S6b, exhibiting a series of peaks at -106, -112, and -115 ppm. The peak at -106 ppm corresponds to the framework Si(OSi)3(OAl) species (Q4) [59,60]. The signals at -112 and -115 ppm are assigned to the framework Si(OSi)4 species at two different crystallographic sites (Q4) [60,61]. Noticeably, the shape and intensity of these peaks are almost unchanged, suggesting the preserve of ZSM-5 framework structure after dealumination. This result is consistent with the XRD and NH3-TPD results. The metal-support interactions of Ni-based catalysts can be characterized by H2-TPR techniques. Fig. 7 shows the H2-TPR curves of pure NiO and 5%Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by different methods (MSSIE, SSIE, DP and IM), and the corresponding H2 consumptions are listed in Table 2 . As shown in Table 2, the total H2 consumptions of all the 5%Ni/ZSM-5 samples are similar, indicating the presence of similar Ni contents. Clearly, the MSSIE, SSIE, DP and IM-prepared Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts exhibit two or three obvious reduction peaks. The peak α centered at low temperature (350 and 375 °C) corresponds to the highly dispersed Ni species, which has weak interactions or separated from the support [62,63]. The peak β centered at moderate temperature (395, 399, 405, and 416 °C) is attributed to the bulk NiO nanoparticles [64,65]. The peak γ centered at high temperature (446, 493, 542 and 553 °C) is assigned to the Ni species strongly interacted with the support, i.e. framework Ni species [65,66]. Noticeably, pure NiO shows only two reduction peaks (α and β) at 354 and 388 °C, respectively, suggesting the coexistence of small and large Ni particles. While the Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by MSSIE and SSIE methods show three obvious peaks, and the peaks at 350 and 375 °C indicate the presence of many fine distributed NiO species. As to the IM and DP-prepared Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts, two high temperature reduction peaks (β and γ) without peak α can be observed, indicating the absence of small Ni nanoparticles. Furthermore, the reduction temperatures of these peaks are various with the prepared methods. Especially, the reduction temperatures of peak γ in Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) (centered at 542 °C) and Ni/ZSM-5(SSIE) (centered at 553 °C) samples are much higher than that of Ni/ZSM-5(DP) (centered at 493 °C) and Ni/ZSM-5(IM) (centered at 446 °C) samples, indicating the presence of much strong metal-support interactions in MSSIE and SSIE samples. Fig. 7b shows the H2-TPR curves and the linear relation between Ni loading amounts and H2 consumptions of Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalysts with different Ni contents, and the corresponding results are listed in Table 2. As shown in Fig. 7b, the intensity and peak areas of Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) increase with the increase of Ni contents. And the total H2 consumptions of 3%Ni/ZSM-5, 5%Ni/ZSM-5, 7%Ni/ZSM-5 and 9%Ni/ZSM-5 are 21.7, 30.1, 50.0 and 59.9 μmol, respectively. The linear relations between Ni loading amounts and H2 consumption are shown in Fig. 7c. Clearly, the total H2 consumption shows a good linear relation to the Ni loading amount with an intercept of about 0, suggesting that most of Ni species are successfully loaded onto the ZSM-5 support [67]. While the H2 consumptions of peak γ exhibit two linear relations to the Ni loading amounts. When the Ni content is below 7%, the H2 consumptions (peak γ) increase with the Ni loading amounts. The H2 consumption exhibits an excellent linear relationship to the Ni loading amounts. When the Ni loading amount is higher than 7%, the H2 consumption of peak γ reaches to a constant value of 14.4 μmol, suggesting the saturated incorporation of the Ni species into the ZSM-5 support. To make clear the surface chemical states of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts, the XPS analysis was investigated. Fig. 8 shows the Ni 2p XPS spectra of pure NiO and Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by different methods. Generally, the peaks centered at 853.6, 860.6, 871.7 and 879.3 eV correspond to the multiplet-split Ni 2p3/2, satellite Ni 2p3/2, multplet-split Ni 2p1/2 and satellite Ni 2p1/2 of NiO, respectively [68,69]. While the binding energies at 855.4, 863, 873.1 and 880 eV are attributed to Ni 2p3/2, satellite 2p3/2, Ni 2p1/2 and satellite 2p1/2 of Ni(OH)2, respectively [70,71]. Moreover, the pure NiO, Ni/ZSM-5(DP) and Ni/ZSM-5(IM) catalysts exhibit similar XPS spectra, indicating the main Ni species of NiO. However, the Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalyst shows a new peak centered around 856.5 eV, corresponding to the Ni−OH species. This is probably due to the Ni incorporation into the ZSM-5 structure, forming many Ni−OH-Si linkages [44,48]. 3.4 Discussion Fig. 9 illustrates the possible formation procedure of Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst prepared by MSSIE method. During the dealumination process, a part of Al species are wiped off. And the dealuminated ZSM-5 possesses many defects such as Si−OH [55]. After loading Ni species, a number of Ni2+ would be incorporated into the dealuminated ZSM-5 framework structure. After further reduction by hydrogen, the framework Ni species would transform into Ni nanoparticles. Due to confinement effect of ZSM-5 zeolite, the Ni species cannot grow up, and thus, resulting in many highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles [11,72,73]. While the Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by DP and IM methods possess weak metal-support interactions, in which the Ni species would aggregate into bulk Ni after high temperature treatment. The catalytic performance of 5%Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by different methods were tested for ammonia decomposition reaction at a fixed reaction condition (0.1 g, 30,000 ml h−1 g−1) (Fig. 1), and the influence of Ni contents on the catalytic activity are shown in Fig. 2. As shown in Fig. 1, the MSSIE sample exhibits the best catalytic performance in all the Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts with H2 formation rate of 31.7 mmol min−1 gcat −1 at 650 °C. Previous reports have shown that the Ni particle size and distribution play a key role in the ammonia decomposition reactions [27–30], and the highly dispersed Ni particles with small particle size are more active than bulk Ni particles. As shown in TEM images, the different preparation methods result in various Ni particle size in order of MSSIE > DP > IM, and the increase in Ni particle size leads to the decrease of catalytic activity. Furthermore, the acidity and redox property of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts are very important features, which could also affect the reactant adsorption and activation, and thus, affecting their catalytic performance [74]. As proved by 27Al NMR analysis (Fig. S6), a part of Al species are removed during the dealumination process. Similarly, Inagaki et al. [55] observed that a part of framework Al on ZSM-5 zeolite could be removed by post-synthetic HNO3 treatment, resulting in a unique ZSM-5 zeolite with few acid sites and many Si−OH species. From the NH3-TPD results, the total acidity of the dealuminated ZSM-5 zeolite decreases from 0.275 to 0.158 mmolNH3 g−1, and can be recovered to some extent after loading Ni species. Indeed, the total acidity amount of 5%Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) is a litter higher than that of the raw HZSM-5, suggesting the formation of many new acidic sites (such as Si−OH-Ni linkages). Meanwhile, these Ni species are very important for the formation of highly dispersed and stable Ni nanoparticles [11,72,73]. As proved by H2-TPR techniques, an obvious reduction peak at low temperature range (peak α) can be observed in all the MSSIE samples (Fig. 7), indicating the presence of many highly dispersed Ni species. While, the Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by DP and IM methods possess weak metal-support interactions, and their Ni species would be easily aggregated into large Ni particles at high reaction temperature. This is also in good accordance with the TEM images, further confirming the high catalytic activity of MSSIE sample (Fig. 1). The catalytic stability of Ni-based catalyst in ammonia decomposition is crucial for its practical application due to the sintering of Ni nanoparticles at high reaction temperature [32,33]. Fig. 3 shows the catalytic performance of 5%Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalyst at 650 °C, exhibiting excellent catalytic stability. In Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalyst, a number of Ni species would be incorporated into the ZSM-5 framework structure, forming many Ni-O-Si bonds [44–48]. H2-TPR curves (Fig. 7) and XPS results have well indicated the presence of strong metal-support interactions between Ni and ZSM-5 support in the Ni-ZSM-5(MSSIE) samples. And the strong metal-support interaction played a key role for the formation of highly dispersed and stable Ni nanoparticles [72,73]. Fig. S7 shows the TEM images of 5%Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalyst after 60 h time-on-stream. It is shown that the particle sizes of Ni species keep small after 60 h time-on-stream at 650 °C, suggesting an excellent stability of the Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalyst. So, it can be concluded that the Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by MSSIE method possess the smallest Ni nanoparticles and strongest metal-support interaction as compared to DP- and IM-prepared samples, exhibiting the best catalytic activity and excellent stability. And the superior catalytic performance of the Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalysts indicates the promising utilization in ammonia decomposition reaction. Ammonia decomposition is an endothermic reaction, and the ammonia conversion increases with the reaction temperature. Fig. 10 shows the Arrhenius plots of the 5%Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by IM, DP, SSIE and MSSIE methods. Obviously, the preparation methods have an influence on the apparent activation energy (E a) of the Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts, i.e., the E a values of IM-, DP-, SSIE- and MSSIE-prepared samples are 98.2, 98.1, 97.7 and 88.1 kJ mol−1, respectively. It is notable that the Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalyst exhibits the lowest E a, corresponding to the highest catalytic activity. And the E a over Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) is comparable to that of reported 5%Ru/MgO-DP (83.3 kJ mol−1) [11], and much lower than that of 3%Ni/MRM (116.7 kJ mol−1) [27]. This result is in good accordance with the catalytic performance of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts. Previous studies reported that the E a values of Ni-based catalysts were significantly dependent on the preparation methods and the support kinds, and small Ni particles possess low E a [15,16]. ZSM-5 zeolite possesses large surface area and rich pores which are good for the formation of small and highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles. It is revealed that the Ni/ZSM-5 prepared by MSSIE method possesses the higher dispersion and smaller Ni particles than the DP and IM-prepared samples. Thus, Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalyst has the lowest E a. 4 Conclusions A series of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts were prepared by the IM, DP, SSIE, and MSSIE methods, and used for ammonia decomposition. Among these catalysts, the Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by MSSIE method exhibits the highest catalytic activity and lowest apparent activation energy. At 650 °C, 97.6% ammonia conversion with about 32.7 mmol min−1 gcat −1 H2 formation rate can be achieved over 5%Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalyst, and ammonia conversions over IM-, DP- and SSIE-prepared catalysts are 50.1, 81.3 and 92.9%, respectively. Furthermore, the Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic stability without deactivation for 60 h at 650 °C, indicating a very promising catalyst in ammonia decomposition to COx-free hydrogen. The high catalytic activity and excellent stability of the Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts can be attributed to the highly dispersed and small Ni nanoparticles, strong metal-support interactions and suitable acidity. The different preparation methods can make great influence on the physiochemical properties of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts, and thus, influencing their catalytic performance. Especially, the Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by MSSIE method possess strong metal-support interactions which help the formation of many highly dispersed and stable Ni nanoparticles. And the small and stable Ni species over Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalysts are responsible for the high catalytic activity and excellent thermal stability in ammonia decomposition reaction. coredata.dc:description: A series of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts are prepared by the methods of wet impregnation (IM), deposition-precipitation (DP), solid state ion exchange (SSIE), and modified solid state ion exchange (MSSIE), and used for catalytic decomposition of ammonia to COx-free hydrogen. Their physicochemical properties are characterized by XRD, N2 sorption, TEM, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, solid-state NMR, and XPS techniques. It is revealed that the preparation methods could obviously influence the Ni species and catalytic performance of Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts, and the catalyst prepared by MSSIE method exhibits the best catalytic activity due to the presence of strong metal-support interaction between highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles and ZSM-5 support. The stability testing results showed almost no activity loss over Ni/ZSM-5(MSSIE) catalyst at 650 °C for 60 h, indicating a very promising catalyst for ammonia decomposition.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic decomposition of ammonia to COx-free hydrogen over Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts: A comparative study of the preparation methods
